titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I left Bishopthorpe after breakfast and travelled to Darlington, where Leng met me with the car, & motored me to Auckland, in time for me to go through my letters before lunch. Among them was one from Old Lord Halifax, thanking me for my sermon at Birmingham, of which he had read a report in the Yorkshire Post, and, I suppose, holding out the olive–branch! After lunch I motored to Barnard Castle, & presided over a special meeting of the Governors? to consider how to effect economies in the working of the school. Bircham, was of course, offensive, but there was no explosion. On returning to the castle I wrote a number of letters, & then, after an early dinner, went to the town hall to witness an entertainment arranged by the Waifs & Strays society. In the "interval" I made a short speech in advocacy of the cause, & then went back to the castle.

A long letter reached me from Bishop Knox in answer to my request that he would give me frankly his views about disruption A. its rightfulness B. its likelihood & C. its procedure. He has evidently been thinking over the subject. But I doubt whether there are half a dozen bishops on the Bench who would have the courage to break away however gross the provocation might be. The age of churches is past.
